comments.body: We need to check the that coid has the proper type.

is there a reason why we cannot extend `OnLedgerBuiltin`?
Yes, probably could here.

As far as I can tell, the only reason why `SAnyException` is different from `SAny` is the reference to the message function. But we already have the type here which afaict, is sufficient to get a reference to the message function. Should we aim to unify the two?
I don't know what the mechanism would be to access the message function from the type at speedy runtime.

I don't think we would get anything from unifying SAny and SAnyException. But I also think it's strange to be carrying around a `messageFunction` when the type field should tell you how to find that function. (Indeed messageFunction seems to just be `compileExceptionType(ty)`? I'm sure I'm missing something...)

Either way. Let's make sure we have tests showing this runs in constant stack space.

comments.body: This will be run on every value we get from the ledger and should hence rather be fast. Do we have any idea how expensive `contains` is? Does it get more expensive as we add more versions?

This gets also more expensive as we add more versions. If this becomes an issue,  we could just add a cache in `VersionRange#contains`

Thanks
Should this be the style output by `scalafmt` then?
(Or can that not happen because it requires the programmer to write the trailing `,` ?)

We had some issues with IntelliJ making scalafmt output a trailing comma before. This might now be fixed in the latest version of IntelliJ 2019; haven't tested it. I expect we'll need to upgrade to IntelliJ 2020 before we can, though, which means waiting for the Bazel plugin to support it.
Is this `TODO` crucial for this PR to work or something you want to address in a follow-up PR?
Yup, we made this issue #6523
Does the `1` in `arity1` have a meaning? To me it looks just like `arity`.
Scala wont let this variable be named `arity`. I assume because it already in scope in a parent class. Hence the suffix `1`
I sadly understand.

@nickchapman-da @remyhaemmerle-da What's _operational_ the difference between
```scala
mbCoid.map(SContractId)
```
and
```scala
mbCoid.map { coid => SContractId(coid) }
```
In other words, why would you eta-expand? I've seen changes like this in other places too.

I do not think there is any operational difference. 
However  `machine.returnValue = SOptional(mbCoid.map(SContractId))` is more idiomatic.
should this be: `machine.returnValue = SV.None` ?
and some other places
The `machine.returnValue = ` is in line 343.

I wonder whether you want to check here that the contract ID in `args0` does not clash w.r.t. discriminators. If we reinterpret a tree, the contract ID might come from a `fetchByKey` construct which is translated into a fetch node only. So the fetched contract ID might come out of nowhere. But I'm not sure whether this can happen on this code path.

Here I do not want to check the contract in `args0`. 
The check of contract gathering by contract key should be done in  `SBULookupKey` (done) and in `SBUFetchKey` (currently missing)

comments.body:
Shouldn't `SB(To|From)Template` also get a comment like the primitives above have? E.g.
```
/** $error :: Text -> a */
```
Good catch, thanks! Iâ€™ve added comments.
Doesn't this filter out all `0` characters of the decimal part, also those in `1.0001`?
`filter` is called on  `Option[String]` not in `String`. That is two say it is idempotent all inputs except `Some("0")`.
D'oh, of course. Thank you.
BTW, are you sure that doesn't allow unicode digits?
The answer is that it doesn't allow unicode digits: https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/util/regex/Pattern.html

allowing the leading `+` has the slight disadvantage that we do not have a canonical representation for `Int64` -- the same numbers can be represented in multiple ways. i'm on the fence on whether this is a good thing or not.
If we allow leading zeros, we have the same problem.
Yes, see my own comment below.

I believe we should not restrict parsing to canonical representation. For instance, the final user probably want to parse "1" and "01" in the same way.
Both Haskell and java (and any other languages I can think of) parse "01" and "1" in the same way.

Furthermore, this has no impact on determinism.
do you allow trailing / leading 0s? this regexp does. do we know what that means when parsing?

Please see tests 
https://github.com/digital-asset/daml/pull/1407/files#diff-ae9014deee9be354b39ebd26faa0150b

OK, so the answer is "yes". I'm really on the fence regarding canonical representation. For users it's clearly worse... so going with the current implementation is probably the right thing.

@hurryabit what do you think?
I'm not sure there's value in having a canonical representation for _parsing_. Being lenient seems fine to me.

Note, we are already lenient (though a bit less than here) when parsing decimals from protobu. We accept anything that matches 
``[+-]?[0-9]{1,28}(\.[0-9]{1,10})?``
@remyhaemmerle-da @bitonic Can you please confirm whether this is the right place to fill in the controllers for missing actors.
looks good.
